Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Developing a new theory of discrete angle-preserving surface maps
Award.AbstractNarration:
The study of complex functions is central to modern mathematics, and may be roughly described as the study of angle-preserving maps between surfaces. A recent application of these maps is their use in the processing of data on two-dimensional surfaces in three dimensions, such as data from medical imaging or 3D facial scans. The maps provide a way to obtain standardized coordinates on such surfaces, to aid data comparison. This project will aim to develop a new finite approximation of these surface maps by proving the Riemann mapping theorem, a foundational theorem in the study of complex functions. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Drs. Jian Sun, David Gu, and Feng Luo, noted experts on computational and low-dimensional geometry and topology, at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China.

Given a piecewise flat metric on a compact surface, we may construct it as a gluing of Euclidean triangles, resulting in a geometric triangulation with a finite number of cone points. This research considers a notion of discrete conformality for such metrics that allows for scaling of edge lengths by conformal factors at the cone points, up to Delaunay conditions; and edge flips to transition between Delaunay triangulations. In recent work, a uniformization result was proven, which demonstrated that any such metric is discrete conformal to a metric with equal angle defect (curvature) at each cone point. Furthermore, a discrete Ricci flow realizes this uniformization, and numerous computations of this flow suggest that the resulting piecewise linear maps converge to holomorphic maps as the triangulations become finer. For the case of the disc, attempts will be made to prove this convergence to obtain the classic Riemann mapping theorem. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, various aspects of discrete conformality were investigated during a summer spent at the Mathematical Sciences Center at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. The study of discrete conformality provides the theoretical background for approximations of angle-preserving maps between surfaces. Such maps have found various applications in medical imaging and computer graphics.

During the stay, work was done on the Discrete Riemann Mapping Conjecture, which was proven false and was appropriately modified. The new conjecture describes mapping a region in the plane to an equilateral triangle in an (approximately) angle-preserving way. An example image of such a mapping is provided.

In addition, efforts were made to achieve square tilings of closed surfaces, another notion of discrete conformality. In the months shortly after the program, we were able to produce such tilings from discrete harmonic 1-forms following ideas of Danny Calegari and Brooks, Smith, Stone, and Tutte. An example image of such a tiling is provided.

These results extend our understanding of different notions of discrete conformality, and are of interest to the broader scientific community for their potential applications. They will form the core of the PI's thesis and are being prepared for publication in a refereed journal. The experience has been integral in the PI's graduate training.

In addition, the project has helped to forge strong research relationships between the PI and Chinese researchers in the field. Work was conducted with the host researcher, Prof. Sun Jian, and with Prof. Feng Luo (of Rutgers). The square tiling results have also been of interest to Prof. David Gu (of Stony Brook), and a presentation of the results have been given to him and his lab. The PI looks forward to future collaborations with these researchers and their students.

Lastly, the PI was also able to assist many other EAPSI participants as one of the few with Mandarin capabilities. He assisted them in communicating with their labs and with the Chinese community at-large. He looks forward to playing the same role with other American researchers in future visits or collaborations.
